title: Fix Spotify Discover Weekly personalization decay
prompt: Spotify's Discover Weekly playlist is losing engagement — skip rates are up 15% and saves are down. The algorithm team says the model is fine. Users say, "it used to know me better." You're the PM. How do you diagnose and fix personalization decay without rebuilding the recommendation engine?
problemDefinition: Signals are decaying: skip rates rising and saves dropping despite model health metrics
Perception gap: users feel the playlist "lost its magic" even if relevance is statistically flat
Constraints: you cannot rebuild the core recommendation model in the next 90 days

options.label: Discovery-first
options.text: Run weekly interviews with heavy and churned users to map where the experience feels broken before touching any UI or algorithms.

options.label: Define the wedge
options.text: Pick a single user segment (e.g., ‘taste‑drifters’) and design a targeted fix with clear success criteria.

options.label: Ship UI fixes now
options.text: Add quick changes (refresh button, theme labels) and learn from live behavior. Don’t wait on research.

options.label: Benchmark + experiment
options.text: Compare to best-in-class retention benchmarks and run 2–3 growth experiments per week to lift saves.

questions.text: Users say "it used to know me better." What do you believe?

options.label: Perception problem
options.text: The model might be fine, but expectations shifted. Fix framing and feedback loops.

options.label: Segment mismatch
options.text: The model works overall but fails a high‑value segment. Fix that segment first.

options.label: Feedback decay
options.text: The feedback loop is broken — users aren’t giving the system enough fresh signals.

options.label: Just ship fixes
options.text: Stop debating. Add a refresh button + quick thumbs UI and measure lift this week.

questions.text: What do you optimize for first?

options.label: Retention lift
options.text: Define a clear retention target (e.g., +8% D30) and work backward from that outcome.

options.label: Strategic wedge
options.text: Pick one narrow user wedge and fix the experience end-to-end for them.

options.label: Speed to learn
options.text: Ship two experiments this week and kill anything that doesn’t move saves.

options.label: Evidence quality
options.text: Run weekly interviews + prototype tests until we’re confident about the opportunity space.

theSplit.question: Should Spotify ship UI/feedback fixes immediately, or diagnose the root cause first?

sides.reasoning: User feedback is noisy. Ship fast, measure lift, and iterate based on real behavior.
Without understanding the opportunity space, you’ll ship UI noise that doesn’t fix relevance.
Pick one segment where decay is worst and fix that experience end-to-end.

cagan.name: Marty Cagan
cagan.summary: If you don’t validate the value risk, you’re just adding UI noise
cagan.spicyQuote: If your fix is a ‘refresh’ button without proving the playlist is valuable, you’re treating symptoms, not solving the disease.
breakdown: Value risk: do users still want this playlist, or has the job-to-be-done changed?
Usability risk: do users know how to influence recommendations?
Viability risk: if this decays, it threatens retention and ad revenue
Discovery should validate the outcome before we ship cosmetic fixes
solution: Run discovery interviews with heavy, light, and churned users
Validate whether decay is relevance, novelty, or signal feedback
Prototype 2–3 fixes and test before engineering investment
Ship only the solution that proves value + retention lift
cagan.disagreement: Execution AI Monster’s ‘ship it now’ approach is how you bury yourself in noisy UI experiments. Lenny’s benchmarks are useful, but growth loops don’t help if the underlying value isn’t there. Doshi’s wedge is smart, but he’s still skipping the value-risk validation that tells you *which* wedge is real.
mvp: User interviews across 3 cohorts (heavy, casual, churned)
Prototype tests for refresh, theme labels, and feedback UI
Small cohort experiment with clear go/no-go criteria
Viability review tied to retention impact
metrics: D30 retention lift in test cohort
roadmap: Weeks 1-2: Discovery — interviews, risk mapping, prototype options
Weeks 3-4: Test — cohort experiment on top 2 hypotheses
Weeks 5-6: Ship — release proven fix to 10%
Weeks 7-10: Scale — expand and monitor retention

torres.name: Teresa Torres
torres.summary: Map the opportunity space before you ship fixes
torres.spicyQuote: If we don’t know *why* Discover Weekly feels broken, we’ll just ship features that add noise to the wrong opportunity.
breakdown: Desired outcome must be explicit (e.g., +8% D30 retention)
Map opportunities: relevance decay, novelty decay, weak feedback loops
Use weekly touchpoints to build evidence, not one-off research
Run experiments that test the link between opportunity and outcome
solution: Create an Opportunity Solution Tree for personalization decay
Weekly interviews + prototype tests with heavy and churned users
Run small experiments tied to specific opportunity branches
Ship only after evidence accumulates across multiple touchpoints
torres.disagreement: Cagan’s risk framing is close but still too phase-based — discovery should be continuous, not a 2-week sprint. Lenny and the Execution AI Monster will ship fast, but they’ll be measuring behavior without a clear theory of the opportunity space. Doshi’s wedge is useful once the opportunity is mapped, not before.
mvp: Opportunity Solution Tree with top 3 branches
roadmap: Week 1+: Weekly cadence — interviews + prototype tests
Weeks 2-4: OST build — map and rank opportunities
Week 8+: Evidence-led ship — release only validated fix

doshi.name: Shreyas Doshi
doshi.summary: Pick one segment where decay is worst and fix it end-to-end
doshi.spicyQuote: This is a strategy problem disguised as a tuning problem. Pick a wedge, or you’ll polish mediocrity.
breakdown: The bandaid is falling off: experiments without a strategy won’t stick
We need a wedge segment with outsized impact (e.g., power users)
Pre-mortem the top 3 failure modes before shipping anything
Opportunity cost > ROI: one wedge over ten small fixes
solution: Identify the segment with the largest decay delta
Run a pre-mortem on fixes that could backfire
Ship a focused experience for that segment only
Expand only if the wedge proves durable
doshi.disagreement: Torres and Cagan want more discovery, but you’ll drown in research without a sharp wedge. The Execution AI Monster ships fast but will thrash without strategic focus. Lenny’s growth loops are useful after you fix the core experience — not before.
mvp: Focused rollout to 5% of target segment

lenny.name: Lenny Rachitsky
lenny.summary: Benchmark, experiment, and ship the smallest lift
lenny.spicyQuote: Discover Weekly is a growth loop. If saves are down, the loop is broken. Run three experiments this week and ship the winner.
breakdown: Look at benchmarks: what do great save rates look like?
Find the growth loop: listen -> save -> share -> return
Identify the activation moment for weekly habit
Design experiments that can move the metric 5–10%
solution: Run 3 parallel experiments (refresh, theme labels, feedback UI)
Pick the highest-lift winner after one week
Scale to 20% and iterate
Double down on the loop that improves saves
lenny.disagreement: Torres wants to map the opportunity space, but the data already tells us the loop is broken. Cagan’s risk framing is solid, but we don’t need weeks of interviews to run experiments. Doshi’s wedge is fine, but in growth you need loops, not anecdotes. Execution AI Monster is fast, but without measurement discipline, speed is just thrashing.

exec.name: Execution AI Monster
exec.role: Ship now. Fix later. Win markets.
exec.summary: Ship 3 fixes this week and let data decide
exec.spicyQuote: You can’t diagnose decay in a conference room. Ship a refresh button today and watch what happens tomorrow.
breakdown: Building is discovery — ship to learn
The cost of shipping UI fixes is near-zero
Every week offline is wasted signal
Measure fast, kill fast
solution: Ship refresh, theme labels, and feedback UI this week
Expose to 10% of users immediately
Daily metric review, kill losers fast
Iterate weekly based on live data
exec.disagreement: Cagan and Torres will still be in interviews while engagement decays. Lenny is close but too slow — one week is an eternity. Doshi wants a wedge, but we can ship multiple wedges faster than we can debate one.

mvpOptions.name: Perception Fix Pack
mvpOptions.reason: UI + framing fixes (refresh, theme labels) to restore perceived relevance quickly.

mvpOptions.name: Segment Wedge Fix
mvpOptions.reason: Pick one segment with the largest decay and build a tailored experience.

mvpOptions.name: Evidence-led Discovery
mvpOptions.reason: Run interviews + opportunity mapping before shipping any fixes.

mvpOptions.name: Feedback Loop Repair
mvpOptions.reason: Improve signal collection (thumbs, taste refresh, onboarding prompts).

premortem: UI noise: We ship multiple fixes and confuse users, making trust worse
Segment miss: We optimize for power users and harm casual listeners
Signal bias: More feedback UI biases the model with low-quality signals
vitalQuestion: Is decay driven by relevance drift, novelty fatigue, or broken feedback signals — and which is fastest to prove?
